name: Acute Ischemic Stroke - Diagnosis and Management
content:
ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE:

DEFINITION:
- Sudden onset focal neurological deficit
- Vascular territory distribution
- Symptoms lasting >24 hours or leading to death

CLINICAL PRESENTATION (BE-FAST):
- Balance: Loss of balance, coordination
- Eyes: Vision changes, diplopia
- Face: Facial droop (asymmetric smile)
- Arm: Arm weakness or drift
- Speech: Slurred speech, aphasia
- Time: Time to call 911

NIH STROKE SCALE (NIHSS):
- Score 0-42 (higher = more severe)
- 0: No deficit, 1-4: Minor, 5-15: Moderate, 16-20: Mod-severe, 21-42: Severe
- Used to determine treatment eligibility and prognosis

EVALUATION:

Immediate (<25 minutes):
- Non-contrast CT head (rule out hemorrhage)
- Fingerstick glucose
- Oxygen saturation
- Vital signs, IV access

Laboratory:
- CBC, CMP, PT/INR, PTT
- Troponin, lipid panel
- HbA1c

Advanced imaging:
- CT angiography (CTA) head/neck if thrombectomy candidate
- MRI brain with DWI/ADC (more sensitive, defines ischemia)
- Perfusion imaging (CT or MRI) to assess penumbra

ACUTE TREATMENT:

1. IV THROMBOLYSIS (tPA/Alteplase):
   Eligibility:
   - Onset <4.5 hours (or 3-4.5h with restrictions)
   - No contraindications (hemorrhage, recent surgery, severe hypertension >185/110)
   - Dose: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90mg), 10% bolus, 90% over 60min
   
   Exclusions:
   - ICH on CT, recent stroke/trauma/surgery <3mo
   - Active bleeding, platelets <100K
   - Glucose <50 or >400, SBP >185 or DBP >110

2. MECHANICAL THROMBECTOMY:
   Eligibility:
   - Large vessel occlusion (ICA, MCA-M1)
   - NIHSS ≥6
   - Onset <6 hours (or up to 24h if imaging shows salvageable tissue)
   - mRS 0-1 pre-stroke
   
3. BLOOD PRESSURE MANAGEMENT:
   - If receiving tPA: Target <185/110 before, <180/105 after
   - If not receiving tPA: Permissive hypertension (allow up to 220/120 first 24h)

4. SUPPORTIVE CARE:
   - Aspirin 325mg (after 24h if received tPA, immediately if not)
   - Statin (high-intensity)
   - DVT prophylaxis
   - Swallow evaluation before PO
   - Monitor for complications (hemorrhagic transformation, edema)

SECONDARY PREVENTION:
- Antiplatelet: Aspirin 81mg OR clopidogrel 75mg daily
- Dual antiplatelet (aspirin + clopidogrel) × 21-90 days if minor stroke/TIA
- Anticoagulation if cardioembolic (AFib)
- Statin (atorvastatin 80mg or rosuvastatin 20mg)
- BP control: <140/90 (or <130/80 if high-risk)
- Diabetes management: HbA1c <7%
- Lifestyle: Smoking cessation, exercise, diet

PROGNOSIS:
- tPA reduces disability by 30% if given within 3h
- Thrombectomy NNT = 3-7 for good outcome
